default.title: Shame
default.definition: A painful feeling of humiliation or distress caused by the consciousness of wrong or foolish behavior.
default.contextualMeaning: Can also be used to express regret or disappointment about something, as in 'It's a shame that you can't come.'
default.exampleSentence: It's a shame we have to leave the party so early.
default.etymology: Old English 'scamu', of Germanic origin, related to a verb meaning 'to cover'.

default.title: Statement
default.definition: A definite or clear expression of something in speech or writing.
default.contextualMeaning: A formal declaration or announcement of facts, opinions, or intentions.
default.exampleSentence: The company issued an official statement to address the recent rumors.
default.etymology: From the verb 'state', from Latin 'status' meaning 'state, condition'.

default.title: Negative
default.definition: Consisting in or characterized by the absence rather than the presence of distinguishing features; expressing or implying refusal, disagreement, or denial.
default.contextualMeaning: Describes something that is bad, harmful, or pessimistic.
default.exampleSentence: Try to avoid a negative attitude when facing new challenges.
default.etymology: From late Middle English, via Old French from Latin 'negativus', from 'negare' meaning 'to deny'.

default.title: Reputation
default.definition: The beliefs or opinions that are generally held about someone or something.
default.contextualMeaning: The general estimation in which a person or thing is held by the public.
default.exampleSentence: The restaurant has a reputation for excellent service.
default.etymology: From Latin 'reputatio(n-)', from 'reputare' meaning 'to think over'.

default.title: Rude
default.definition: Offensively impolite or ill-mannered.
default.contextualMeaning: Behavior that shows a lack of respect for other people.
default.exampleSentence: It is considered rude to interrupt someone while they are speaking.
default.etymology: From Latin 'rudis' meaning 'unwrought, rough'.

default.title: Presenter
default.definition: A person who introduces or hosts a television or radio program.
default.contextualMeaning: Someone who presents information to an audience, such as a host, speaker, or lecturer.
default.exampleSentence: The presenter of the news show is well-known for her clear speaking style.
default.etymology: From the verb 'present', via Old French from Latin 'praesentare'.

default.title: Recognised (Recognized)
default.definition: Identified (someone or something) from having encountered them before; acknowledged the existence, validity, or legality of.
default.contextualMeaning: To know someone or something because you have seen or heard them before.
default.exampleSentence: She recognised her old friend from across the room, even after ten years.
default.etymology: From 're-' (again) + Middle English 'knowlechen' (acknowledge).

default.title: Crucial
default.definition: Decisive or critical, especially in the success or failure of something.
default.contextualMeaning: Extremely important or necessary for a particular situation or outcome.
default.exampleSentence: Getting enough sleep is crucial for good health.
default.etymology: From French 'crucial', from Latin 'crux, cruc-' meaning 'cross'.

default.title: Perceived
default.definition: Became aware or conscious of (something); came to realize or understand.
default.contextualMeaning: How something is interpreted or regarded by someone; the way one understands or sees a situation.
default.exampleSentence: He perceived a change in her attitude towards the project.
default.etymology: From Old French 'perçoivre', from Latin 'percipere' meaning 'to seize, understand'.

default.title: Conventional
default.definition: Based on or in accordance with what is generally done or believed.
default.contextualMeaning: Following the traditional or widely accepted forms and standards.
default.exampleSentence: He chose a conventional suit for the job interview instead of something more fashionable.
default.etymology: From late Latin 'conventionalis', from Latin 'conventio(n-)' meaning 'agreement, meeting'.

default.title: Informal
default.definition: Having a relaxed, friendly, or unofficial style, manner, or nature.
default.contextualMeaning: Suitable for everyday situations rather than official or formal ones.
default.exampleSentence: The company has an informal dress code on Fridays.
default.etymology: From 'in-' (not) + 'formal'.

default.title: Interpreted
default.definition: Explained the meaning of (information, words, or actions).
default.contextualMeaning: Understood an action, word, or situation in a particular way.
default.exampleSentence: She interpreted his silence as a sign of disapproval.
default.etymology: From Latin 'interpretari', from 'interpres, interpret-' meaning 'explainer'.

default.title: Threatening
default.definition: Having a hostile or deliberately frightening quality or manner.
default.contextualMeaning: Appearing as if it might cause harm or danger.
default.exampleSentence: The dark, threatening clouds suggested a storm was coming.
default.etymology: From the verb 'threaten', from Old English 'þrēat' meaning 'oppression'.

default.title: Quite
default.definition: To the utmost or most absolute extent or degree; completely. To a certain or fairly significant extent or degree; moderately.
default.contextualMeaning: Used to add emphasis or to mean 'to some degree'. For example 'quite good' means fairly good.
default.exampleSentence: The movie was quite interesting, although a little long.
default.etymology: From Middle English, originally in the sense 'entirely, freely', from Old French 'quite'.

default.title: Kindly
default.definition: (As adverb) In a kind manner. (As adjective) Kind, warm-hearted, or gentle.
default.contextualMeaning: Behaving in a way that is pleasant, friendly, and good-natured.
default.exampleSentence: She has a kindly smile that makes everyone feel welcome.
default.etymology: Old English 'gecyndelīce' meaning 'naturally', later influenced by 'kind'.

default.title: Offensive
default.definition: Causing someone to feel deeply hurt, upset, or angry.
default.contextualMeaning: Describes something that is disagreeable and causes resentment or moral outrage.
default.exampleSentence: His comments were deeply offensive to many people in the audience.
default.etymology: From French 'offensif, -ive', from 'offenser', from Latin 'offendere'.

default.title: Aggressive
default.definition: Ready or likely to attack or confront; characterized by or resulting from aggression.
default.contextualMeaning: Behaving in a forceful or angry way that can be frightening to others.
default.exampleSentence: The driver became aggressive when someone took his parking spot.
default.etymology: From Latin 'aggress-', from the verb 'aggredi', meaning 'to attack'.

default.title: Civil
default.definition: Courteous and polite.
default.contextualMeaning: Relates to maintaining a minimum level of politeness and courtesy, even if not being warm or friendly.
default.exampleSentence: Even though they disagreed, their debate remained civil.
default.etymology: From Latin 'civilis', from 'civis' meaning 'citizen'.

default.title: Offence (Offense)
default.definition: An act or remark that causes annoyance, upset, or resentment.
default.contextualMeaning: The state of being hurt or upset by someone's actions or words.
default.exampleSentence: Please don't take offence at my comments; I was only trying to help.
default.etymology: From Old French, via Latin from 'offendere' meaning 'strike against'.

default.title: Society
default.definition: The aggregate of people living together in a more or less ordered community.
default.contextualMeaning: A large group of people who share a culture, institutions, and a common territory.
default.exampleSentence: Every member of society has a responsibility to help others.
default.etymology: From French 'société', from Latin 'societas', from 'socius' meaning 'companion'.

default.title: Repeatedly
default.definition: Over and over again; constantly or frequently.
default.contextualMeaning: Describes an action that happens many times.
default.exampleSentence: He repeatedly checked his watch while waiting for the train.
default.etymology: From the verb 'repeat', from Old French 'repeter', from Latin 'repetere'.

default.title: Mention
default.definition: Refer to (something) briefly and without going into detail.
default.contextualMeaning: To speak or write about something in a brief, often casual way.
default.exampleSentence: Did she mention where she was going for her vacation?
default.etymology: From Latin 'mentio(n-)', related to 'mens, ment-' meaning 'mind'.

default.title: Embarrassment
default.definition: A feeling of self-consciousness, shame, or awkwardness.
default.contextualMeaning: The uncomfortable feeling you get when you do something foolish or awkward in front of other people.
default.exampleSentence: To his embarrassment, he forgot the name of his host.
default.etymology: From French 'embarrasser', from Spanish 'embarazar', probably from a Portuguese word based on 'baraça' meaning 'a noose'.

default.title: Strong
default.definition: Having the power to move heavy weights or perform other physically demanding tasks; existing in a high degree; intense.
default.contextualMeaning: In this context, it means very intense or powerful, not physically.
default.exampleSentence: She has a strong desire to travel the world.
default.etymology: Old English 'strang', of Germanic origin.

default.title: Unspecified
default.definition: Not stated clearly or in detail.
default.contextualMeaning: Used to describe something that is known to exist but has not been given a specific name, time, or detail.
default.exampleSentence: The package will arrive at an unspecified time tomorrow.
default.etymology: From 'un-' (not) + the past participle of 'specify'.

default.title: Quiz
default.definition: A test of knowledge, especially as a competition between individuals or teams as a form of entertainment.
default.contextualMeaning: A short test to check understanding or knowledge.
default.exampleSentence: The teacher gave the students a short quiz at the end of the lesson.
default.etymology: Late 18th century: perhaps from Latin 'qui es?' meaning 'who are you?', the first question in a Latin grammar test.

default.title: Worksheet
default.definition: A paper listing questions or tasks for students.
default.contextualMeaning: A document with exercises or problems for someone to complete.
default.exampleSentence: Please complete the math worksheet for homework tonight.
default.etymology: From 'work' + 'sheet'.
